answers.author: Christopher Anderson
answers.text:
We recently conducted our community survey online. We mailed a notice to every resident giving instructions on how to participate. We also posted the link on our website. We encouraged people without computer access to use computers in the library or at city hall. We had paper copies available for those who didn't feel comfortable with computers. We ended up with about a 23% response rate, compared to a typical 40% rate. Not sure why, and this might be entirely atypical, but that was our experience.

answers.author: Kristin Zagurski
answers.text:
Gregory, We also did an online survey this year. A bit of information from our final report; the full report is at CRgov.com/2011survey.
The quantitative survey was distributed in a multi-modal approach that combined a survey link distributed via email, on the town’s website and on postcards mailed to Town business owners. Hard copies were also available. The survey link was sent to 1,872 resident email addresses, and postcards advertising the link were sent to all 3,150 Castle Rock business license holders. The survey yielded 1,491 responses. Of those, 1,086 were complete, non-duplicated, and usable responses, providing an overall response rate of approximately 25%.
